description: From Latin triptōtum, from Ancient Greek τρίπτωτος (tríptōtos), from τρι- (tri-, “three”) +‎ πίπτω (píptō, “to fall”) +‎ -τος (-tos, verbal adjective–forming suffix), influenced by the verbal noun πτῶσις (ptôsis, “inflection”).

entries.meaning: (grammar) A noun which has three cases.
examples: In Modern Standard Arabic, nouns belong to triptotes or diptotes, or can be indeclinable.
